title_full: SLSSEC01-BP01 Use AWS_IAM authorization for API Gateway with least-privileged permissions
title: Use AWS_IAM authorization for API Gateway with least-privileged permissions
description: For consumers within your AWS environment or with means to retrieve IAM temporary credentials, use AWS_IAM authorization and add least-privileged permissions to the respective IAM role to securely invoke your API. Implement tag-based access control for better API-level control on resources and actions.

title_full: SLSSEC01-BP02 Use Lambda authorizers for custom authentication with existing Identity Providers
title: Use Lambda authorizers for custom authentication with existing Identity Providers
description: If you have an existing Identity Provider (IdP), use an API Gateway Lambda authorizer to invoke a Lambda function to authenticate or validate users. Lambda authorizers can send additional information derived from bearer tokens or request context to your backend service, limiting exposure of authorization data to just the authorization function.

title_full: SLSSEC01-BP03 Use Amazon Cognito user pools for user management and social identity federation
title: Use Amazon Cognito user pools for user management and social identity federation
description: If you don't have an existing IdP, leverage Amazon Cognito user pools for built-in user management or integration with external identity providers like Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and Amazon. This approach provides granular authorization through OAuth Scopes and is common for mobile backend scenarios.

title_full: SLSSEC01-BP04 Use API Gateway resource policies to restrict API access
title: Use API Gateway resource policies to restrict API access
description: Attach JSON policy documents to APIs to control whether specified AWS Principals can invoke the API. Restrict invocations by users from specified AWS accounts, source IP address ranges or CIDR blocks, and specified VPCs or VPC endpoints. Use private endpoints for APIs that should only be accessed from within your VPC.

title_full: SLSSEC01-BP05 Configure mutual TLS authentication for application-to-application scenarios
title: Configure mutual TLS authentication for application-to-application scenarios
description: For IoT or application-to-application authentication scenarios, configure mutual TLS (mTLS) authentication where clients present certificates to verify identity when accessing API Gateway endpoints. Combine mTLS with Lambda authorizers for more granular authorization mechanisms.

title_full: SLSSEC01-BP06 Use AWS WAF to protect APIs against common web attacks
title: Use AWS WAF to protect APIs against common web attacks
description: Use AWS WAF to add protection for your APIs on the application network layer. Use managed rule groups to protect against well-known attacks like SQL injection and cross-site scripting (XSS). Create custom rule groups for additional requirements specific to your application.

title_full: SLSSEC02-BP01 Follow least-privileged access for Lambda function IAM roles
title: Follow least-privileged access for Lambda function IAM roles
description: Follow least-privileged access and only allow the access needed to perform a given operation. Attaching a role with more permissions than necessary can open your systems for abuse. Having smaller functions that perform scoped activities contributes to a more well-architected serverless application.

title_full: SLSSEC02-BP02 Avoid sharing IAM roles across multiple Lambda functions
title: Avoid sharing IAM roles across multiple Lambda functions
description: Avoid sharing an IAM role within more than one Lambda function as this will likely violate least-privileged access. Each function should have its own IAM role with only the permissions required for that specific function's operations.

title_full: SLSSEC02-BP03 Use cross-account Lambda authorizers to centralize security practices
title: Use cross-account Lambda authorizers to centralize security practices
description: For large deployments with multiple AWS accounts, use cross-account Lambda authorizers in API Gateway to reduce maintenance and centralize security practices. Lambda authorizers can be created and managed in a separate account and reused across multiple APIs. Amazon Cognito user pools can also be used from a separate account.

title_full: SLSSEC03-BP01 Validate and sanitize inbound events
title: Validate and sanitize inbound events
description: Validate and sanitize inbound events and perform security code reviews as you would for non-serverless applications. For API Gateway, set up basic request validation to ensure requests adhere to configured JSON-schema request models and required parameters. Implement application-specific deep validation as a separate Lambda function, library, or service.

title_full: SLSSEC03-BP02 Use AWS Signer to sign Lambda code and enforce trusted deployments
title: Use AWS Signer to sign Lambda code and enforce trusted deployments
description: Add code signature to protect against unintended and unauthorized changes while code moves through CI/CD pipelines. Signing confirms code comes from a trusted source and is unaltered. AWS Signer integrates with AWS Lambda to sign code and enforce that only trusted code is deployed into your runtime.

title_full: SLSSEC03-BP03 Store secrets in AWS Secrets Manager with rotation capabilities
title: Store secrets in AWS Secrets Manager with rotation capabilities
description: Store secrets such as database passwords or API keys in a secrets manager that allows for rotation, secure and audited access. Secrets Manager allows fine-grained policies for secrets including auditing. Never send credentials or sensitive data through query string parameters or headers.

title_full: SLSSEC03-BP04 Encrypt sensitive data at all layers before processing
title: Encrypt sensitive data at all layers before processing
description: Encrypt sensitive data at the client-side before making HTTP requests, or send it as payload via HTTP POST. Within Lambda functions, encrypt sensitive data before any processing or data manipulation to prevent data leakage if exposed in persistent storage or standard output streamed to CloudWatch Logs.

title_full: SLSSEC03-BP05 Track vulnerabilities in application dependencies
title: Track vulnerabilities in application dependencies
description: Track vulnerabilities in application dependencies because attackers can exploit known vulnerabilities found in dependencies regardless of programming language. Use commercial or open-source solutions like OWASP Dependency Check that integrate within your CI/CD pipeline. Include all dependencies including AWS SDKs as part of your version control repository.

title_full: SLSSEC03-BP06 Configure Lambda VPC access only when necessary
title: Configure Lambda VPC access only when necessary
description: Configure Lambda functions to access resources within a VPC only when necessary. Control traffic at all layers as described in the AWS Well-Architected Framework. For VPC-enabled functions needing internet access, set up a NAT gateway configured across multiple Availability Zones for high availability and performance.

title_full: SLSSEC03-BP07 Use dynamic IAM authentication for service-to-service communication
title: Use dynamic IAM authentication for service-to-service communication
description: For service-to-service communication, favor dynamic authentication using temporary credentials with AWS IAM over static keys. API Gateway and AWS AppSync both support IAM Authorization, making it ideal to protect communication to and from AWS services.
